questions.text:
A 5-year-old patient presented with difficulty in micturition. On doing a USG examination, the following image was seen in the bladder. It shows an outpouching arising from both VUJ in bladder.

What is the expected IVP finding?
questions.solution:
Ureteroceles are congenital abnormalities characterized by the abnormal dilatation of the distal ureter, which may herniate into the bladder due to structural issues at the vesico-ureteric junction (VUJ). Bulging is due to a failure in the regression of the Chwalla membrane during development.

Fluoroscopy/Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP)

  • Cobra Head Sign:
    • A key finding where a filling defect is seen in the bladder. The ureterocele may appear distended, collapsed, or everted.

  • Radiolucent Halo Effect:
    • Surrounding the filling defect, this halo represents the abnormal dilated ureter.
  • Bladder Diverticulum Appearance:
    • An everted ureterocele can mimic a bladder diverticulum.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Various IVP appearances

Ureterocele - Cobra head

Duplex kidney- Drooping Lily

Retrocaval Ureter - J shaped

Horseshoe kidney - Handholding sign/ Flower vase Sign

Retroperitoneal fibrosis - Maiden waist appearance

Cobra head or adder head appearance of ureterocele on IVP:

Drooping Lily sign on IVP: DUPLEX KIDNEY:

J shaped ureter on IVP seen with Retrocaval ureter:

Flower vase appearance on IVP seen in condition called Horseshoe kidney

Maiden waist appearance in IVP seen with Retroperitoneal fibrosis

questions.text: A 3-year-old patient presented with recurrent urinary tract infections. On eliciting history, there was some difficulty while passing urine. He was advised to undergo a MCU examination. It is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Vesico-ureteric reflux (VUR) is the abnormal flow of urine from the bladder back into the upper urinary tract (ureters and kidneys). It is most commonly seen in young children and is associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs) and pyelonephritis.

Diagnostic Procedures

  1. Voiding Cystourethrogram (VCUG):
    • The primary diagnostic method for evaluating VUR. This fluoroscopic procedure involves filling the bladder with contrast and taking images while the child voids, allowing assessment of reflux.
  2. Other Diagnostic Methods:
    • Nuclear Medicine Studies:
      • MAG3 (Mercaptoacetyltriglycine): Useful as a screening tool, especially in older patients, to evaluate renal function and detect reflux.
    • Ultrasound:
      • Can assess for hydronephrosis and other anatomical abnormalities but is less sensitive for detecting reflux compared to VCUG.
    • MR Voiding Cystography:
      • An emerging non-invasive technique that uses MRI to visualize the bladder and assess for reflux.
  • PUJ obstruction will have ballooning of only pelvis and normal ureters.
  • Horseshoe kidney shows hand holding sign on IVP
  • duplex pelvicalyceal system, two renal pelvis and ureters are noted.

KEY TAKE AWAY: -

Grades of VUR

VUR is classified into five grades based on the severity of reflux observed during VCUG:

questions.text: A patient had a history of RTA. He underwent prolonged urethral catheterization, now presented with a history of poor flow in the urine. The physician advised him for an RGU. It is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Urethral strictures are relatively common and typically occur either in the setting of trauma or infection (gonorrhea).
  • Fluoroscopy : Provides real-time imaging of the urethra during contrast injection, aiding in functional assessment.
  • Retrograde Urethrography (RUG) : The primary imaging method for anterior urethral strictures, allowing detailed visualization of the stricture.
  • Posterior Urethral Strictures: After blunt trauma, a combination of antegrade cystourethrography and retrograde urethrography is often necessary to accurately measure the urethral defect.

Key Takeaway:

  • Urethral injury with leak will show contrast extravasation into the surrounding tissues
  • Ureteral stricture will be diagnosed with IVP
  • Urethral stone will be seen as solitary opacity.

URETERAL STRICTURE:-

questions.text: A patient presented with back pain radiating to the pelvic region. He was advised to undergo an IVP examination. Based on the symptoms what is the most likely IVP image which could be obtained?
questions.solution:
• Ureteric stones are calculi located within the ureter, extending from the ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) to the vesicoureteric junction (VUJ).
  • Symptoms:
    • Renal Colic: Classic peristaltic pain often described as severe and colicky.
    • Additional Symptoms: Hematuria, nausea, and vomiting.

Pain Characteristics

  • Location of Calculi:
    • UPJ: Deep flank pain due to renal capsule distension, usually without radiation to the groin.
    • Upper Ureter: Flank and lumbar pain, may radiate to the groin.
    • Mid-Ureter: Anteriorly and caudally radiating pain; may mimic appendicitis or diverticulitis.
    • Distal Ureter: Groin pain, often referred from the genitofemoral or ilioinguinal nerves.

Imaging Techniques

  • Non-Contrast CT (CT KUB):
    • Gold Standard: Highly sensitive and specific for ureteric stones.
    • Detects stones >1 mm, with nearly 100% specificity.
    • Can identify features of collecting system dilation and delayed nephrogram due to distal obstruction.

On IVP

  • Dilation of the Collecting System: Hydronephrosis: IVP can demonstrate hydronephrosis (dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces) secondary to obstruction by a stone, indicating a blockage.
  • Delayed Imaging: IVP often includes delayed images to evaluate the excretion of contrast from the kidneys, which can help identify any obstruction and the degree of renal function.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

choices.text: Any of the upper or lower

questions.text: A 1-year-old child presented with complaints of fever and excessive crying while passing urine. He was advised to undergo an USG examination. The USG examination showed presence of a duplex pelvicalyceal system and double ureters. Among the two systems which is more likely to be refluxing?
questions.solution:
The duplication of the renal collecting system is indeed the most common congenital urinary tract anomaly, typically arising from the development of two ureteric buds from a single Wolffian duct. This condition results in the formation of an upper and lower renal moiety, each with its own ureter.

  • Ureteric Bud Development: The anomaly occurs when two ureteric buds form from one Wolffian duct, leading to duplicated renal systems.
  • Ureter Insertion:
    • Lower Pole Ureter: Usually inserts normally into the trigone of the bladder, maintaining a standard anatomical position.
    • Upper Pole Ureter: Often has an ectopic insertion, which can occur medially and inferiorly within the bladder, or in some cases, it may insert into the urethra, vagina, or uterus in females, and into the ejaculatory duct in males.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Weigert–Meyer Law: This law illustrates the relationship between the ureters of the upper and lower renal moieties:
    • The upper pole ureter typically inserts medial and inferior to the lower pole ureter.
    • This arrangement is often linked with a ureterocele, which can cause obstruction of the distal ureter.

DUPLEX PELVI CALYCEAL SYSTEM:-

questions.text: Match the following IVP images with their diagnoses
questions.solution:
KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Various IVP appearances

Ureterocele - Cobrahead

Duplex kidney- Drooping Lily

Retrocaval Ureter - J shaped

Horseshoe kidney - Handholding sign/ Flower vase Sign

Retroperitoneal fibrosis - Maiden waist appearance

questions.text: A patient presented with loin pain and fever. He was advised to undergo a CT IVP which is shown below. What is the name of the staging system used for grading of these lesions?
questions.solution:
Renal cysts are commonly encountered in clinical practice and necessity for further investigation or intervention depends on the cyst complexity and the presence of any underlying predisposing conditions.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

questions.text:
A patient presented with seizures to an emergency department. On undergoing a CT scan of the brain, subependymal nodules were found. On further examination the skin of the patient revealed the following finding

For confirmation of the diagnosis and further management, an abdominal CT scan was done. What is the expected finding?
questions.solution:
Based on given history it is likely Tuberous Sclerosis, and the renal feature seen with it is angiomyolipoma.

Angiomyolipomas (AMLs) are benign renal tumors characterized by a mixture of fat, smooth muscle, and abnormal blood vessels.

Characteristics of Angiomyolipomas:

  • Risk of Hemorrhage:
    • The risk of hemorrhage increases with tumor size, especially in lesions larger than 4 cm in diameter.
  • Ultrasound Appearance:
    • Typically appears as a circumscribed, highly reflective mass, often more echogenic than surrounding renal sinus fat.
  • CT Characteristics:
    • CT scans typically reveal a fatty mass with areas of increased tissue density, though the fat content can vary and may sometimes be absent.
    • Diagnosis is supported by the detection of fat within the mass, with an attenuation value of −15 HU being diagnostic for fat.
  • Angiography Findings:
    • Angiographic studies may reveal multiple aneurysms and an "onion layer" appearance due to the vascular components of the tumor.

FEATURES OF TUBEROUS SCLEROSIS:

A) Facial angiofibroma. B) Forehead plaque. C) Subungual fibromas. D)Hypomelanotic macules. E) Shagreen patch. F) Dental enamel pits. G) Angiomyolipoma. H) Cortical tubers. I) Subependymal nodules.

KEY TAKE AWAY: -

Renal angiomyolipoma

questions.text: A patient presented with difficulty in urination and frequent episodes of lower UTI. On doing an Xray of the KUB region, the following image was obtained. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bladder calculi are urinary stones located primarily in the urinary bladder and can be classified based on their origin:

Types of Bladder Stones:

  1. Primary Bladder Stones:
    • Form in the absence of other urinary tract abnormalities.
    • Commonly seen in children, particularly in endemic areas.
  2. Secondary Bladder Stones:
    • Develop in an abnormal bladder environment or from foreign materials, such as urinary catheters.
    • Often associated with conditions like bladder outlet obstruction or chronic urinary retention.
  3. Migratory Stones:
    • Typically, renal calculi that have migrated down into the bladder, though this is uncommon.

Imaging Evaluation:

  1. Plain Radiograph:
    • Appearance:
      • Bladder stones are usually densely radiopaque, appearing as white spots on the X-ray.
      • They can be single or multiple and are often large.
      • Internal lamination can be observed, resembling the layers of an onion.
  2. Ultrasound:
    • Findings:

Stones appear mobile, echogenic, and produce posterior acoustic shadowing.

  • May be associated with bladder wall thickening due to inflammation or irritation from the stones.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Schistosomiasis generally presents with calcification along the bladder wall.
  • Hip AVN will shows sclerosis and deformed femoral heads.

questions.text: A young 13-year-old male patient came to OPD with a complaint of on and off central abdominal pain. He was advised to undergo a USG of the abdomen. It revealed multiple enlarged lymph nodes in the pre-aortic and para-aortic region. No other significant abnormality was obtained in the USG of the abdominal region. What organ should be screened next?
questions.solution:
Germ cell tumors (GCTs) of the testes are the most common type of testicular cancer, primarily affecting young men. They can be classified into several subtypes, including seminomas and non-seminomatous germ cell tumors (NSGCTs).

Imaging Techniques:

  1. Ultrasound (US):
    • Initial Imaging Modality: Often the first imaging test performed for scrotal masses.
    • Findings:
      • Typically presents as a hypoechoic
      • May have increased vascularity on Doppler imaging.
      • Seminomas may appear homogeneous, while NSGCTs can be heterogeneous.
      • Can assess for associated hydrocele or lymphadenopathy.
  2. Computed Tomography (CT):
    • Staging and Evaluation: CT of the abdomen and pelvis is performed to assess for metastatic disease.
    • Findings:
      • Enlarged retroperitoneal lymph nodes are common in NSGCTs.
      • May demonstrate soft tissue masses or infiltrative lesions.
      • Assess for organ involvement or distant metastases (lungs, liver).

KEY TAKE AWAY: -

Key Imaging Features:

  • Seminomas:
    • Usually well-circumscribed, homogeneous, and hypoechoic on ultrasound.
    • Associated with lymphadenopathy in advanced stages.
  • Non-Seminomatous Germ Cell Tumors (NSGCTs):
    • May present as heterogeneous masses with cystic and solid components.
    • Often associated with elevated tumor markers (e.g., AFP, hCG).
  • Chest neoplastic lesions metastasize to adrenal and liver.
  • Arm and leg lesions metastasize to liver.

questions.text: A 1-day old newborn child presented with scrotal swelling. On examination it was non-warm and non-tender. A USG was advised which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Hydroceles are fluid collections between the layers of the tunica vaginalis that can be either congenital or acquired. They typically present as painless scrotal enlargement.

Types of Hydroceles:

  1. Congenital Hydroceles:
    • Communicating Hydrocele:
      • Occurs when fluid accumulates around a patent processus vaginalis that has not obliterated.
    • Spermatic Cord Hydrocele:
      • Encysted Hydrocele (Spermatic Cord Cyst):
        • A cyst that does not communicate with the peritoneum or tunica vaginalis.
      • Funicular Hydrocele (Funiculocele):
        • Communicates with the peritoneum at the internal ring but does not surround the testis.
        • More common in children and premature infants.
  2. Acquired Hydroceles:
    • Can result from trauma, infection, or other inflammatory processes.

Imaging Evaluation:

  • Ultrasound (US):
    • First-Line Modality:
      • Hydroceles appear as simple, anechoic fluid collections surrounding the testis or spermatic cord.
      • Typically, avascular on Doppler evaluation.
      • May contain septations, calcifications, or cholesterol deposits.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

  • Epididymitis presents with bulky epididymis and increased vascularity on USG.
  • Orchitis presents with bulky testes and increased vascularity on USG
  • Spermatocele presents with fluid with internal echoes

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presented with an abdominal lump. He also underwent an abdominal X Ray which showed an ill defined non calcified soft tissue density lesion in the region of the kidney. On CT scan, a heterogeneously enhancing lesion was seen arising from the kidney. Which of the following conditions is not associated with the given lesion?
questions.solution:
Wilms tumor, or nephroblastoma, is the most common renal malignancy in children, typically presenting as an asymptomatic abdominal mass.

Clinical Symptoms:

  • Asymptomatic abdominal mass. Hematuria, Pain, fever

Syndromes with Predisposition:

  • Aniridia: Absence of the iris.
  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome: Characterized by macroglossia, exomphalos, and gigantism.
  • Hemihypertrophy
  • Denys-Drash syndrome: Pseudo hermaphroditism.
  • Sotos syndrome: Cerebral gigantism.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

questions.text: A 5-month-old child presented with abdominal swelling. On examination it was found to be a hard palpable mass. On doing a Xray, a soft tissue lesion was seen in the abdomen showing calcification within it. He was advised to undergo a CT scan which showed a heterogeneous lesion arising from the adrenal gland. Which of the following clinical syndrome is not associated with the above mentioned lesion?
questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma is a malignant neoplasm that arises from primordial neural crest cells and is the most common extracranial solid tumor in children.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Typical Age of Diagnosis: Median age is 2 years.
  • Symptoms:
    • Incidental abdominal mass or abdominal pain.
    • Symptoms often related to metastatic disease, which may include:
      • Bone and joint pain.
      • Proptosis (eye bulging) from orbital metastases.
      • Anemia, weight loss, and fever.
      • Horner syndrome: Presenting with cervical or thoracic neuroblastoma affecting the stellate ganglion.
      • Hormonal symptoms:
        • Catecholamines: Hypertension.
        • Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP): Intractable watery diarrhea.
      • Myoclonic encephalopathy of infancy (MEI): A paraneoplastic syndrome associated with neuroblastoma.

Imaging Evaluation:

  1. Conventional Radiography:
    • May show a calcified mass in the thorax or abdomen.
    • Erosion of vertebral pedicles may indicate intraspinal extension.
  2. Ultrasound (US):
    • Essential for diagnosis, especially in infants and children.
    • Findings:
      • Prenatal or neonatal adrenal neuroblastoma may appear cystic, solid, or heterogeneous.
      • Doppler US is useful to assess vascularization:
  3. Computed Tomography (CT):
    • Large, Heterogeneous Mass: Often with calcifications

KEY TAKE AWAY:-
